Question: OPR-001 - The term "flight time" is defined as...
Option A: the period from the start of the take-off run to the final touchdown when landing.
Option B: the total time from the first aircraft movement until the moment it finally comes to rest at the end of the flight.
Option C: the period from engine start for the purpose of taking off to leaving the aircraft after engine shutdown.
Option D: the total time from the first take-off until the last landing in conjunction with one or more consecutive flights.
Answer: the total time from the first aircraft movement until the moment it finally comes to rest at the end of the flight.

Question: OPR-002 - What should be considered regarding a scheduled flight over water, when land cannot be reached in case of an emergency landing?
Option A: Transponder code 7600 has to be set during the whole flight
Option B: Contact to the nearest ATC shall consist during the whole flight
Option C: For all passengers there must be life jackets or lifeboats present
Option D: The flight plan has to contain the exact waypoints
Answer: For all passengers there must be life jackets or lifeboats present

Question: OPR-003 - Which of the items below may have an influence on the noise perceived by a person on the ground? 1) Engine power setting 2) Propeller revolutions per minute 3) Position of the landing gear 4) Flap position 5) Flight track 6) Height above ground 7) Flight rules
OPR-004 - How can the pilot of an engine-driven aircraft minimise the noise emission during descent and approach?
Option A: Normal approach with normal power setting, configuration prior to initiating descent, shortest possible arrival route
Option B: Descent and approach in landing configuration while maintaining a descent angle of 3°, direct approach whenever possible
Option C: Low approach with minimum power setting, late configuration and steep approach, adherence to established arrival routes
Option D: High approach with minimum power setting, late descent, late configuration, adherence to established arrival routes
Answer: High approach with minimum power setting, late descent, late configuration, adherence to established arrival routes

Question: OPR-005 - When should turns at low altitudes above villages be avoided with regard to noise abatement procedures?
Option A: In descent
Option B: In climb
Option C: During the approach
Option D: In horizontal flight
Answer: In climb

Question: OPR-006 - How should departures near villages be carried out?
Option A: Slow with a low propeller rotation speed
Option B: Low and fast between the villages
Option C: Climb and changes in direction should be done as slow as possible
Option D: Villages should be circumnavigated and crossed in a sufficient altitude
Answer: Villages should be circumnavigated and crossed in a sufficient altitude

Question: OPR-007 - Which kind of engine is susceptible to carburettor fire?
Option A: Piston engines
Option B: Turbine engines
Option C: Electric motors
Option D: Turboprop engines
Answer: Piston engines

Question: OPR-008 - Why is it dangerous to pump the throttle for engine start in cold weather?
Option A: It may cause a carburettor fire
Option B: Carburettor icing can occur
Option C: The engine might start with not enough power
Option D: The oil will become diluted
Answer: It may cause a carburettor fire

Question: OPR-009 - Which danger exists during engine start?
Option A: Cable fire
Option B: Carburettor fire
Option C: Sparking
Option D: Smoke emission
Answer: Carburettor fire

Question: OPR-010 - May an engine, which previously was on fire, be restarted?
Option A: No, the risk of a reignition of the fire would be too high
Option B: Yes, if the aircraft is flying at a safe altitude
Option C: Yes, but only on the ground for the purpose of taxiing
Option D: Yes, but only if the cause of the fire was a carburettor fire during engine start
Answer: No, the risk of a reignition of the fire would be too high

Question: OPR-011 - Which gas is most dangerous during an engine fire?
Option A: Carbon monoxide
Option B: Nitrogen
Option C: Oxygen
Option D: Carbon dioxide
Answer: Carbon monoxide

Question: OPR-012 - Smoke enters the cockpit during an engine fire. Which actions have to be taken immediately?
Option A: Switching off the master switch and the ignition
Option B: Switching off the heating and the ventilating system
Option C: Switching off the pitot and front window heating
Option D: Switching off the avionics and the cabin lighting
Answer: Switching off the heating and the ventilating system

Question: OPR-013 - What should be the first action in case of a cable fire during a flight?
Option A: Close the fuel valve
Option B: Open the windows
Option C: Turn off the master switch
Option D: Open cabin ventilation
Answer: Turn off the master switch

Question: OPR-014 - What extinguishing agent is the least suitable for an aircraft fire?
Option A: Powder
Option B: Halon
Option C: Water
Option D: Foam
Answer: Water

Question: OPR-015 - In flight, a little smoke emerges from behind the instrument panel. An electrical fire is suspected. Which action, with respect to the pilot's operating manual, should be taken?
Option A: Turn off the heat
Option B: Shut down the engine
Option C: Turn off the master switch
Option D: Use the fire extinguisher
Answer: Turn off the master switch

Question: OPR-016 - In flight, a little smoke emerges from behind the instrument panel. An engine fire is suspected. Which action, with respect to the pilot's operating manual, should be taken?
Option A: Turn off the heat
Option B: Shut down the engine
Option C: Use the fire extinguisher
Option D: Turn off the master switch
Answer: Turn off the heat

Question: OPR-017 - A wind shear is...
Option A: a slow increase of the wind speed in altitudes above 13000 ft.
Option B: a wind speed change of more than 15 kt.
Option C: a vertical or horizontal change of wind speed and wind direction.
Option D: a meteorological downslope wind phenomenon in the alps.
Answer: a vertical or horizontal change of wind speed and wind direction.

Question: OPR-018 - Which weather phenomenon is typically associated with wind shear?
Option A: Fog.
Option B: Invernal warm front.
Option C: Thunderstorms.
Option D: Stable high pressure areas.
Answer: Thunderstorms.

Question: OPR-019 - When do you expect wind shear?
Option A: During an inversion
Option B: In calm wind in cold weather
Option C: During a summer day with calm winds
Option D: When passing a warm front
Answer: During an inversion

Question: OPR-020 - During an approach the aeroplane experiences a windshear with a decreasing headwind. If the pilot does not make any corrections, how do the approach path and the indicated airspeed (IAS) change?
Option A: Path is higher, IAS decreases
Option B: Path is lower, IAS increases
Option C: Path is higher, IAS increases
Option D: Path is lower, IAS decreases
Answer: Path is lower, IAS decreases

Question: OPR-021 - During an approach the aeroplane experiences a windshear with an increasing headwind. If the pilot does not make any corrections, how do the approach path and the indicated airspeed (IAS) change?
Option A: Path is higher, IAS decreases
Option B: Path is lower, IAS increases
Option C: Path is higher, IAS increases
Option D: Path is lower, IAS decreases
Answer: Path is higher, IAS increases

Question: OPR-022 - During an approach the aeroplane experiences a windshear with a decreasing tailwind. If the pilot does not make any corrections, how do the approach path and the indicated airspeed (IAS) change?
Option A: Path is higher, IAS decreases
Option B: Path is higher, IAS increases
Option C: Path is lower, IAS decreases
Option D: Path is lower, IAS increases
Answer: Path is higher, IAS increases

Question: OPR-023 - After take-off an aeroplane gets into a wind shear with decreasing headwind. As a result...
Option A: the aeroplane flies above the estimated climb path.
Option B: the true airspeed (TAS) will increase.
Option C: the ground speed (GS) will decrease.
Option D: the aeroplane flies below the estimated climb path.
Answer: the aeroplane flies below the estimated climb path.

Question: OPR-024 - How may windshear be recognised in flight?
Option A: Sudden and apparently baseless change in altitude, airspeed, rate of climb or descent.
Option B: Sudden and apparently baseless change in heading, turning rate, engine speed or oil temperature.
Option C: Sudden and apparently baseless change of oilpressure, oil temperature, engine speed and altitude.
Option D: Rather unexpected onset of drizzle associated with high stratus clouds following previously clear skies and calm conditions.
Answer: Sudden and apparently baseless change in altitude, airspeed, rate of climb or descent.

Question: OPR-025 - Which phenomenon may be expected at point 2 of the microburst?
Option A: Constant rate of descent
Option B: Decrease of descent rate
Option C: Increase of airspeed
Option D: Decrease of climb rate
Answer: Decrease of climb rate

Question: OPR-026 - Which phenomenon may be expected at point 3 of the microburst?
Option A: Decrease in airspeed
Option B: Constant rate of descent
Option C: Increase in airspeed
Option D: Decrease in climb rate
Answer: Decrease in airspeed

Question: OPR-027 - How can a wind shear encounter in flight be avoided?
Option A: Avoid take-off and landing during the passage of heavy showers or thunderstorms
Option B: Avoid areas of precipitation, particularly during winter, and choose low flight altitudes
Option C: Avoid take-offs and landings in mountainous terrain and stay in flat country whenever possible
Option D: Avoid thermally active areas, particularly during summer, or stay below these areas
Answer: Avoid take-off and landing during the passage of heavy showers or thunderstorms

Question: OPR-028 - What action should be taken when entering a windshear? 1. Reduce speed 2. Retract gear and flaps 3. Maintain current configuration 4. Adjust thrust
Option A: 2 and 4
Option B: 1 and 2
Option C: 1 and 3
Option D: 3 and 4
Answer: 3 and 4

Question: OPR-029 - After lift-off, a much stronger than expected airspeed rise is experienced during the initial climb phase. What may be expected if the aeroplane entered a microburst?
Option A: An increased climb rate and decreased airspeed
Option B: An increased climb rate and airspeed
Option C: A decreased climb rate and airspeed
Option D: A decreased climb rate and increased airspeed
Answer: A decreased climb rate and airspeed

Question: OPR-030 - Immediately after lift-off, a microburst is entered inadvertently. Which action might avoid an unintentional descent?
Option A: Set maximum power, maintain present aircraft configuration, climb at the best rate of climb speed
Option B: Set maximum power, retract landing gear and flaps, pick up speed and perform a left or a right turn in an attempt to leave the area of the microburst on the shortest way
Option C: Set maximum power, retract landing gear and flaps, increase pitch until attaining optimum climb speed
Option D: Set maximum power, maintain present aircraft configuration, pick up speed in an attempt to leave the area of the microburst as fast as possible
Answer: Set maximum power, maintain present aircraft configuration, climb at the best rate of climb speed

Question: OPR-031 - Wake turbulences develop during take-off just as the aeroplane...
Option A: reaches an altitude of 15 ft.
Option B: lifts off with the main gear.
Option C: lifts off with the front gear.
Option D: accelerates.
Answer: lifts off with the front gear.

Question: OPR-032 - Wake turbulence is caused by...
Option A: wind shear at the wingtip of an aerofoil.
Option B: jet blast behind a turbine engine.
Option C: turbulence at the downwind side of a mountain range.
Option D: pressure compensation at the wingtip of an aerofoil.
Answer: pressure compensation at the wingtip of an aerofoil.

Question: OPR-033 - Wake turbulence is particularly strong...
Option A: when flying at high speeds.
Option B: when flying at high altitudes.
Option C: when flying at low speeds.
Option D: when flying at low altitudes.
Answer: when flying at low speeds.

Question: OPR-034 - Wake turbulence is particularly strong...
Option A: at a high aeroplane weight.
Option B: when flying with high thrust.
Option C: when flying with low thrust.
Option D: at a low aeroplane weight.
Answer: at a high aeroplane weight.

Question: OPR-035 - The intensity of wake turbulence depends on...
Option A: the propeller pitch.
Option B: the temperature.
Option C: the weight of the aeroplane.
Option D: the altitude of the aeroplane.
Answer: the weight of the aeroplane.

Question: OPR-036 - Two aircraft of the same type, same grossweight and same configuration fly at different airspeeds. Which aircraft will cause more severe wake turbulence?
Option A: The aircraft flying at lower altitude.
Option B: The aircraft flying at slower speed.
Option C: The aircraft flying at higher speed.
Option D: The aircraft flying at higher altitude.
Answer: The aircraft flying at slower speed.

Question: OPR-037 - Two aircraft of the same type, same gross weight and same flap configuration fly with different speeds and altitude. Which aircraft will cause more wake turbulence?
Option A: The aircraft flying at a higher altitude
Option B: The aircraft flying at a lower altitude
Option C: The aircraft flying at higher speed.
Option D: The aircraft flying at lower speed.
Answer: The aircraft flying at lower speed.

Question: OPR-038 - With only a slight crosswind, what is the danger at take-off after the departure of a heavy aeroplane?
Option A: Wake turbulence on or near the runway.
Option B: Wake turbulence is amplified and distorted.
Option C: Wake turbulence rotate faster and higher.
Option D: Wake turbulence twisting transverse to the runway.
Answer: Wake turbulence on or near the runway.

Question: OPR-039 - A light aircraft intends to land behind a commercial airliner belonging to wake turbulence category "medium" or "heavy" on a long runway. How can the wake turbulence of the commercial aircraft be avoided?
Option A: By making a steep approach and a long landing, touching down behind the touchdown point of the airliner's nose gear
Option B: By making a steep approach and a very short landing. The light aircraft should be able to stop before reaching the airliner's touchdown point
Option C: By making a shallow approach and a long landing, touching down behind the touchdown point of the airliner's nose gear
Option D: By making a shallow approach and a very short landing. The light aircraft should be able to stop before reaching the airliner's touchdown point
Answer: By making a steep approach and a long landing, touching down behind the touchdown point of the airliner's nose gear

Question: OPR-040 - What should be observed when taxiing behind a commercial airliner?
Option A: To avoid wake turbulence, a minimum distance of 700 m should be maintained
Option B: To avoid the jet blast, a minimum distance of 600 m should be maintained
Option C: To avoid wake turbulence, a minimum distance of 300 m should be maintained
Option D: To avoid the jet blast, a minimum distance of 200 m should be maintained
Answer: To avoid the jet blast, a minimum distance of 200 m should be maintained

Question: OPR-041 - A technical fault requires an emergency off-field landing. Which steps, with respect to the pilot's operating handbook, are necessary?
Option A: Inform air traffic control and request technical support, check the pilot's operating handbook for a reference on the matter and execute an emergency landing.
Option B: Reduce speed and configure the aircraft for landing in an attempt to gain time, declare an emergency, complete the applicable emergency procedure and execute an emergency landing.
Option C: Locate a suitable landing area, plan the approach, complete the applicable emergency procedure, declare an emergency, start and concentrate on the approach in due time.
Option D: Declare an emergency, complete the applicable emergency procedure, cover as much distance towards the airport as possible to be closer to the rescue forces.
Answer: Locate a suitable landing area, plan the approach, complete the applicable emergency procedure, declare an emergency, start and concentrate on the approach in due time.

Question: OPR-042 - Which method is appropriate to approach an unprepared landing field?
Option A: Flat direct approach to ensure visual ground contact
Option B: Steep approach to keep the noise level low
Option C: Fast approach, performance check, and landing within a quick stop
Option D: Terrain investigation to determine approach points and landing
Answer: Terrain investigation to determine approach points and landing

Question: OPR-043 - Which area is suitable for an off-field landing?
Option A: Harvested cornfield
Option B: Glade with long dry grass
Option C: Plowed field
Option D: Sports area in a village
Answer: Harvested cornfield

Question: OPR-044 - An emergency landing is a landing...
Option A: conducted without power from the engine.
Option B: conducted in an attempt to keep up safety regarding an aircraft and its occupants.
Option C: conducted with the flaps retracted.
Option D: conducted in response to circumstances forcing the aircraft to land.
Answer: conducted in response to circumstances forcing the aircraft to land.

Question: OPR-045 - A landing conducted in response to circumstances forcing the aircraft to land is a / an...
Option A: precautionary landing.
Option B: urgent landing.
Option C: emergency landing.
Option D: field or out landing.
Answer: emergency landing.

Question: OPR-046 - A precautionary landing is a landing...
Option A: conducted without power from the engine.
Option B: conducted in response to circumstances forcing the aircraft to land.
Option C: conducted in an attempt to sustain flight safety.
Option D: conducted with the flaps retracted.
Answer: conducted in an attempt to sustain flight safety.

Question: OPR-047 - Which of the following landing areas is most suitable for an off-field landing?
Option A: A lake with an undisturbed surface
Option B: A light brown field with short crops
Option C: A meadow without livestock
Option D: A field with ripe waving crops
Answer: A light brown field with short crops

Question: OPR-048 - How does the pilot prepare for a VFR flight over a large distance of water, when it is unlikely that land can be reached in case of an engine failure?
Option A: File a flight plan including the exact way-points.
Option B: Be prepared to fly with transponder only.
Option C: Carry life vests or a life raft for all occupants.
Option D: Maintain continuous radio contact with ATC.
Answer: Carry life vests or a life raft for all occupants.

Question: OPR-049 - Which items should a passenger briefing in case of an imminent emergency landing include?
Option A: How to work the aircraft radio, emergency transponder squawk, telephone number of the competent search and rescue (SAR) center
Option B: Blood type of the other aircraft occupants, location of the first-aid kit
Option C: Nature of the emergency, intentions, safety position, evacuation routes, actions after landing
Option D: How to read an emergency checklist, how to cut the engine, telephone number of the home airport
Answer: Nature of the emergency, intentions, safety position, evacuation routes, actions after landing

Question: OPR-050 - After a precautionary landing the brakes and wheels are very hot. In which way should the pilot approach them?
Option A: From the right or left side
Option B: At an angle of 45°
Option C: From the front or back side
Option D: From the front, right or left side
Answer: From the front or back side

Question: OPR-051 - What needs to be observed in conjunction with overheated brakes?
Option A: The affected brakes need to be cooled down with halon
Option B: The affected tyres may burst in axial direction
Option C: The affected tyres may burst in radial direction or direction of rotation
Option D: The wheel fairing shall be taken off to increase the cooldown
Answer: The affected tyres may burst in axial direction

Question: OPR-052 - In case of an emergency ditching, the life vests have to be inflated...
Option A: before disembarking the aircraft.
Option B: during disembarking the aircraft.
Option C: after disembarking the aircraft at a safe distance of about 10 m.
Option D: after disembarking the aircraft.
Answer: after disembarking the aircraft.

Question: OPR-053 - What are the effects of wet grass on the take-off and landing distance?
Option A: Decrease of the take-off distance and increase of the landing distance
Option B: Increase of the take-off distance and increase of the landing distance
Option C: Decrease of the take-off distance and decrease of the landing distance
Option D: Increase of the take-off distance and decrease of the landing distance
Answer: Increase of the take-off distance and increase of the landing distance

Question: OPR-054 - Under which circumstances may a runway be considered to be contaminated?
Option A: When more than 25 % of the runway surface area within the required length and width being used is covered by water, slush, snow or ice more than 3 mm deep
Option B: When 75 % of the required runway length and width are covered by contaminants such as snow, frost, ice or sand
Option C: When more than 50 % of the runway surface area within the required length and width being used is covered by water, slush, snow or ice more than 3 mm deep
Option D: When more than 50 % of the required runway length and width are covered by contaminants such as snow, frost, ice or sand
Answer: When more than 25 % of the runway surface area within the required length and width being used is covered by water, slush, snow or ice more than 3 mm deep

Question: OPR-055 - What minimum coverage with ice or snow must be given to call a runway "contaminated"?
OPR-056 - Wet snow on a runway can lead to...
Option A: an increase in lift.
Option B: a decrease in lift.
Option C: reduced rolling resistance during take-off.
Option D: increased rolling resistance during take-off.
Answer: increased rolling resistance during take-off.

Question: OPR-057 - What danger does standing water on the runway pose to aircraft?
Option A: Decreased rolling resistance during take-off
Option B: An increase in lift
Option C: Increased rolling resistance during take-off
Option D: A decrease in lift
Answer: Increased rolling resistance during take-off

Question: OPR-058 - Which danger exists after a heavy rain shower for a landing aircraft?
Option A: Displacement of the tire slip marking
Option B: Difficult flare due to glare
Option C: Longer braking distance due to aquaplaning
Option D: Decreased braking distance due to aquaplaning
Answer: Longer braking distance due to aquaplaning

Question: OPR-059 - Which would be the correct reaction when hydroplaning is suspected upon landing?
Option A: Add power and use flaps and spoilers to brake aerodynamically
Option B: Apply maximum braking to reduce aircraft speed to less than hydroplaning speed, then continue normal ground roll
Option C: Cross rudder and aileron controls in order to use the aircraft fuselage to brake aerodynamically
Option D: If all wheels are in motion, brake moderately. Maintain directional control by aerodynamic means
Answer: If all wheels are in motion, brake moderately. Maintain directional control by aerodynamic means

Question: OPR-060 - How should a landing on a contaminated runway be conducted if it proves to be inevitable?
Option A: Approach with the minimum crosswind component possible, use minimum flaps, touch down softly with positive pitch and minimum speed, do not apply brakes
Option B: Approach with the minimum crosswind component possible, use maximum flaps, touch down with negative pitch and minimum speed, brake carefully
Option C: Approach with the minimum crosswind component possible, use maximum flaps, touch down firmly with minimum speed, brake carefully
Option D: Approach with the minimum crosswind component possible, use minimum flaps, touch down softly with minimum speed, do not apply brakes
Answer: Approach with the minimum crosswind component possible, use maximum flaps, touch down firmly with minimum speed, brake carefully

Question: OPR-061 - During final approach, the glider pilot realizes a very bumpy surface on a selected off-field landing site. What technique may be recommended for landing?
Option A: Touch down with minimum speed, compensate different ground levels with power lever
Option B: Approach with increased speed, push elevator upon first ground contact
Option C: Touch down with minimum speed, keep elevator pulled until full stop
Option D: Approach with increased speed, avoid using wheel brakes
Answer: Touch down with minimum speed, keep elevator pulled until full stop
